data.title: Derek Fisher of the Los Angeles Lakers leaves Nike for Adidas
data.meta_description: Fisher was intrigued with the possibility of working with Adidas after his playing career ends.
data.text:
Derek Fisher, the Los Angeles Lakers veteran point guard, has left Nike and signed a shoe endorsement contract with Adidas.

Terms of the deal are confidential, but Fisher, 36, was intrigued with the possibility of working with Adidas after his playing career ends, said Chris Grancio, Adidas head of global sports marketing.

Grancio said Fisher and Adidas agreed to the deal last week after having begun talks two weeks ago.

"We had the opportunity to go over to him to talk about our brand," Grancio said in a phone interview from his Adidas North America office on North Greeley Avenue, "and he found our presentation interesting and compelling."

Fisher, president of the

, reflects Adidas values through his professional and personal life, Grancio said.

"He's incredibly committed to charities in the community," he said of Fisher, who played at the University of Arkansas-Little Rock.

Fisher joins the two players Grancio identified as the centerpieces of the Adidas basketball brand, Derrick Rose of the Chicago Bulls and Dwight Howard of the Orlando Magic.

Fisher had previously endorsed Nike basketball shoes for 10 of his 14 years in the NBA, according to Nick DePaula of

a website that reported on the deal Monday.

Fisher's arrival to the Adidas camp follows the departure this summer of Boston Celtics forward

who signed in May with the Chinese footwear maker ANTA, according to solecollector.com.
